clinical_study.brief_title: 2D Versus 3D Laparoscopic Training on a Virtual Reality Simulator
clinical_study.official_title: 2D Versus 3D Laparoscopic Training on a Virtual Reality Simulator - A Randomised Trial

brief_summary.textblock: Laparoscopy training programs with virtual reality simulators are widely used before new surgeons are allowed to operate on patients. Laparoscopic surgery results in shorter time to recover, less surgical trauma and thereby a shorter stay at the hospital compared with open surgery. However, it is more difficult to learn laparoscopic surgery, than open surgery, in part because surgeons have to work in a 3-dimensional space, through a 2-dimensional interface on a screen. This results in loss of depth perception and therefore a higher visual and cognitive load. This trial examines if using 3D vision instead of 2D vision on the laparoscopic virtual reality simulator reduces the time to reach proficiency, by decreasing the cognitive and visual load during practice on a Virtual Reality Simulator.

primary_outcome.measure: Time (minutes) to reach the predefined proficiency level for the basic skills and the salpingectomy procedure

secondary_outcome.measure: Time (minutes) to reach the predefined proficiency level for the basic skills and salpingectomy procedure under 2D conditions after 3-6 weeks without laparoscopic training during the follow-up period

other_outcome.measure: Workload: NASA TLX questionnaire after the first and fifth attempt on procedural module,
Visual and physical discomfort questionnaire after each training session (adverse effect: eye strain, headache, dizziness, nausea, tired and sore neck/back),

arm_group.description: Will practice under 3D vision conditions on a laparoscopic virtual reality simulator
Will practice under 2D vision conditions on a laparoscopic virtual reality simulator

intervention.description: Laparoscopic simulator training to proficiency under 3D conditions
Laparoscopic simulator training to proficiency under 2D conditions

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Residents working in Denmark. Participants are required to have a medical license and provide informed consent before inclusion
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Participation in prior studies involving laparoscopic training.
2. Experience with laparoscopy surgery (having performed minimum one laparoscopic procedure as primary surgeon, including supervised procedures).
3. Performing more than 3 supervised laparoscopy surgeries during the intervention.
4. Performing laparoscopy surgery between the intervention and the retention test 3-6 weeks after.
5. No informed consent.
6. Does not speak Danish on a conversational level.
